data.title: 1993 – 1995 Mighty Morphin Power Rangers
data.meta_description: Mighty Morphin 93-95 / Zeo 96 / Turbo 97 / In Space 98 / Lost Galaxy 99 / Lightspeed Rescue 00 / Time Force 01 / Wild Force 02 / Ninja Storm 03 / Dino Thunder 04 / SPD 05 / Mystic Force 06 / Operation Overdrive 07 / Jungle Fury 08 / RPM 09…
data.text:
Mighty Morphin 93-95 / Zeo 96 / Turbo 97 / In Space 98 / Lost Galaxy 99 / Lightspeed Rescue 00 / Time Force 01 / Wild Force 02 / Ninja Storm 03 / Dino Thunder 04 / SPD 05 / Mystic Force 06 / Operation Overdrive 07 / Jungle Fury 08 /RPM 09 / Mighty Morphin 10 /

Mighty Morphin Power Rangers 1993 – 1995

The Power Rangers began their mega successful run in the U.S market in 1993, after being adopted from the popular Japanese version, Super Sentai. This version of the show was called the “Mighty Morphin Power Rangers” and it ran until 1995, with toys being released until the beginning of 1996. The toy line showed massive sales numbers and proved to be only the beginning of this powerhouse franchise. Bandai released several sub-sets, vehicles, and accessories for the Mighty Morphin line, and it remains the largest Power Rangers line produced to date.

For more information about Bandai’s Mighty Morphin Power Rangers line, see bottom of the page for a complete summary.

Mighty Morphin Power Rangers (1993): Basic Figures (2200)

The first series of figures released in 1993 featured the original five Rangers, in a triangular box with bright green and yellow colors. These figures are the ones most fans remember from growing up in the 1990’s.

Mighty Morphin Power Rangers (Basic Series)

Year Released: 1993

Scarcity Factor: Can still be found, but getting tougher to find each year.

Notes: This was the very first line of Power Ranger figures to ever hit the toy shelves back in 1993, and stores had trouble keeping up with the massive demand at the time. These figures had little in the way of articulation but were painted well with solid sculpting.

Evil Space Aliens (1993 – 1994): Basic Figures (2210)

Bandai changed the packaging just a bit for the bad guys, by making it a more conventional squared box with a yellow/blue tone. There were seven Evil Space Aliens released in this series from 1993-1994.

King Sphinx

Market Value:

Boxed $25 – $40

Loose $7 – $13

Putty Patrol

Market Value:

Boxed $25 – $40

Loose $7 – $13

Squatt

Market Value:

Boxed $30 – $45

Loose $7 – $13

Evil Space Aliens (Series 1)

Year Released: 1993, 1994

Scarcity Factor: Can still be found, but getting tougher to find each year.

Notes: This was the first series of bad guys for the Power Ranger line to be released in 1993, and proved very popular. They are not terribly difficult to find on the secondary market because so many of each were produced.

Karate Action Power Rangers (1994): Basic Figures (2201)

This series of Power Rangers figures once again featured all five of the original Rangers, but with a new “Karate Action” feature. The packaging was a traditional squared shape with the same bright green/yellow colors.

Karate Action Power Rangers

Year Released: 1994

Scarcity Factor: Easily found on the secondary market.

Notes: This series of Ranger figures once again featured each of the original five Rangers, but Bandai added a karate kicking action feature. The figures lacked articulation and were mass produced in large numbers, making them easy to find nowadays.

Deluxe Evil Space Aliens (1994): Basic Figures (2211)

The Deluxe Evil Space Aliens series featured six new Evil Space Aliens in a “Deluxe” format, meaning they all came with fancy weapons. This series also saw the first figure of the Power Rangers main villain, Lord Zedd.

Goo Fish

Market Value:

Boxed $15 – $25

Loose $5 – $10

Guitardo

Market Value:

Boxed $20 – $30

Loose $5 – $10

Lord Zedd

Market Value:

Boxed $20 – $30

Loose $5 – $10

Pirantis Head

Market Value:

Boxed $15 – $25

Loose $5 – $10

Rhino Blaster

Market Value:

Boxed $15 – $25

Loose $5 – $10

Socadillo

Market Value:

Boxed $20 – $30

Loose $5 – $10

Deluxe Evil Space Aliens (Series 1)

Year Released: 1994

Scarcity Factor: Can still be found, but getting tougher to find each year.

Notes: This was the second series of bad guys for the Power Ranger line, but were released as Deluxe Evil Space Aliens. This wave contained all new different characters, including the iconic Lord Zedd.

Auto-Morphin Power Rangers (1994): Basic Figures (2310)

The “Auto-Morphin” series was an extremely popular one when released in 1994, mostly due to the Power Rangers show hitting its pinnacle around this time. The series featured all five original Rangers, along with the very first figure of Tommy, the Green Ranger.

Auto-Morphin’

Billy

Market Value:

Carded $25 – $40

Loose $8 – $15

Auto-Morphin’

Jason

Market Value:

Carded $25 – $40

Loose $8 – $15

Auto-Morphin’

Kimberly

Market Value:

Carded $25 – $40

Loose $8 – $15

Auto-Morphin’

Tommy

Market Value:

Carded $50 – $75

Loose $15 – $25

Auto-Morphin’

Trini

Market Value:

Carded $25 – $40

Loose $8 – $15

Auto-Morphin’

Zach

Market Value:

Carded $25 – $40

Loose $8 – $15

Auto-Morphin Power Rangers

Year Released: 1994

Scarcity Factor: Can still be found, but getting tougher to find each year.

Notes: The Auto-Morphin Power Ranger figures were incredibly popular because for the first time, kids were finally able to see the human faces of their favorite Ranger characters through the “Auto-Morphin” process, which was basically a head that would flip around to see each face version. Another huge note about this series was it was the first that featured the fan favorite character, Tommy the Green Ranger.

Action Feature Aliens (1994): Series 1 Figures (2320)

The Action Feature Aliens series featured 12 bad guys in a slightly smaller scale, but all came with new “Action Features”. All were brand new releases to the toy line and featured many popular baddies from the television show.

Action Feature Evil Space Aliens (Series 1)

Year Released: 1994

Scarcity Factor: Can still be found, but getting tougher to find each year.

Notes: This was the first series of bad guys for the Power Ranger line in the standard 5″ format. This was a large series, and a very fun one too because of the wide variety of characters released. They were produced in large numbers, which is why they are not difficult to find on the secondary market.

Action Feature Aliens (1995): Series 2 Figures (2350)

The second wave of the Action Feature Aliens series, released in 1995, added six more bad guys to the “Action Features” line. Most were brand new releases to the series, except for Lord Zedd and Goldar, who had been seen before in the Deluxe Evil Aliens series.

Action Feature Evil Space Aliens (Series 2)

Year Released: 1995

Scarcity Factor: Can still be found, but getting tougher to find each year.

Notes: This was the second series of bad guys for the Power Ranger line in the standard 5″ format. The new wave was not as big as the first, but did feature several new characters, including the popular Putty Patrol and Lord Zedd.

Talking Power Rangers (1995): 8″ Figures (2390)

Bandai released the “Talking Power Rangers” in 1995, which included the original five Rangers, and Tommy, who converted from green to white. In addition a Talking Lord Zedd figure was also released, but in a different packaging style.

Talking Red Ranger

Market Value:

Boxed $40 – $60

Loose $12 – $20

Talking White Ranger

Market Value:

Boxed $75 – $100

Loose $25 – $40

Talking Yellow Ranger

Market Value:

Boxed $40 – $60

Loose $12 – $20

Talking 8″ Power Rangers

Year Released: 1995

Scarcity Factor: Can still be found, but getting tougher to find each year.

Notes: The Talking Power Ranger figures were incredibly popular because for the first time, kids were finally able to hear the voices of their favorite Ranger characters. Even though Tommy the Green Ranger had been released the year prior in 1994, this was the first series that featured Tommy as the White Ranger, making it among the more popular figures of the line.

Movie Edition Power Rangers (1995): 5.5″ Figures (2420)

The Mighty Morphin Power Rangers Feature Movie was released in 1995, and proved to be extremely popular with the fan base, so movie figures seemed like a no-brainer. The 5.5″ figures included all six Rangers on a new movie style blister card.

Movie Edition 5.5″ Power Rangers

Year Released: 1995

Scarcity Factor: Can prove a bit difficult to track down, but can still be found on the secondary market.

Notes: The Power Ranger movie in 1995 proved extremely popular with fans and audiences, so a new line of figures from the movie was inevitable. This series was very popular because of the metallic appearance of the characters, with Tommy the White Ranger being the most popular figures of the series.

Movie Edition Evil Space Aliens (1995): 5.5″ Figures (2450)

In addition to the Movie Ranger figures, Bandai also released four new Evil Space Aliens figures from the movie in a 5.5″ version. This included three new movie characters, along with Lord Zedd.

Movie Edition Evil Space Aliens

Year Released: 1995

Scarcity Factor: Can still be found, but getting tougher to find each year.

Notes: This series of bad guys featured four of the characters seen on the big screen for the mega successful Power Ranger movie, released in 1995. Mordant and Tengu Warrior were brand new figures, and can prove a bit tougher to track down than the other two.

Movie Edition Power Rangers (1995): 8″ Figures (2430)

Since the feature Power Rangers movie proved to be so popular in 1995, Bandai released a series of 8″ figures as well as the previously mentioned 5.5″ versions. Once again, this series included all six Rangers.

Movie Edition 8″ Power Rangers

Year Released: 1995

Scarcity Factor: Can prove a bit difficult to track down, but can still be found on the secondary market.

Notes: The Power Ranger movie in 1995 proved extremely popular with fans and audiences, so new figures from the movie was inevitable. This 8 inch series was released just after the 5.5 inch wave, and of course proved very popular, with Tommy the White Ranger being the toughest to find of the series.

Movie Edition Evil Space Aliens (1995): 8″ Figures (2488)

The three main villains from the Power Rangers movie in 1995 were released in a “deluxe” 8″ version.

Hornitor

Market Value:

Boxed $75 – $100

Loose $35 – $50

Ivan Ooze

Market Value:

Boxed $40 – $60

Loose $12 – $20

Scorpitan

Market Value:

Boxed $75 – $100

Loose $35 – $50

Movie Edition 8″ Evil Space Aliens

Year Released: 1995

Scarcity Factor: Can still be found, but getting tougher to find each year.

Notes: This series of bad guys featured three of the characters seen on the big screen for the mega successful Power Ranger movie, released in 1995. Ivan Ooze was also found in the smaller 5.5″ format, but Hornitor and Scorpitan were new and remain harder to find nowadays on the secondary market.

Special Edition Auto-Morphin’ (1995): Metallic Figures (2560)

The Rangers were released in a new “Special Edition” version in the Fall of 1995, which featured each character in a new metallic version. The original yellow/green packaging was also brought back.

Special Edition Auto-Morphin Power Rangers

Year Released: 1995

Scarcity Factor: Tough to find on the secondary market.

Notes: The first Auto-Morphin Power Ranger series was incredibly popular, so it was brought back in a “special edition” with the new figures having a metallic appearance. The “Auto-Morphin” process, was basically a head that would flip around to see the human face of each character. This set can be difficult to find on the secondary market.

Auto Morphin’ Power Rangers Series 2 (1995): Basic Figures (2440)

The Auto-Morphin series was brought back with a second wave in the Fall of 1995, but only included four of the seven Rangers for some reason.

Auto-Morphin Power Rangers (Series 2)

Year Released: 1995

Scarcity Factor: Tough to find on the secondary market.

Notes: The Auto-Morphin Power Ranger figures were incredibly popular in 1994, so a second wave was released in the Fall of 1995. This wave featured the first Auto-Morphin White Ranger figure. This set was among the last waves of releases for the Ranger line and can be tough to find on the secondary market.

Action Evil Space Aliens (1995): Basic Figures (2460)

If new Ranger figures are continually being released, then it only makes sense that new bad guys for them to fight should also be released. This series of baddies each came with new action features.

Action Feature Evil Space Aliens (Series 3)

Year Released: 1995

Scarcity Factor: Can still be found, but getting tougher to find each year.

Notes: This was the third series of bad guys for the Power Ranger line in the standard 5″ format. Like the previous two waves, this one featured all new figures with fun action features. Rito Revolto and Master Vile remain among the harder to find of the series.

Deluxe Evil Space Aliens (1995): Series 2 (2521)

A second wave of Deluxe Evil Space Aliens was released in 1995, featuring six new figures.

Deluxe Evil Space Aliens (Series 2)

Year Released: 1995

Scarcity Factor: Some can be tougher than others to track down on the secondary market.

Notes: This was the second series of deluxe bad guys for the Power Ranger line, with the first being released the year prior in 1994. The series contained a mix of new and previously released characters, and can be tougher to track down due to being a late released for the line in the Fall of 1995.

Action Ninja Rangers (1995): Basic Figures (2470)

This set of figures featured the six Ranger characters with Ninja costumes. Notice the two female Rangers (Pink and Yellow) are actually wearing skirts……

Action Ninja Rangers

Year Released: 1995

Scarcity Factor: Can still be found, but getting tougher to find each year.

Notes: The Action Ninja Power Ranger figures were not terribly popular when released in 1995, mostly due to the blocky appearance of the characters and poor articulation.

Battle Borgs (1996): Basic Figures (2660)

The final set of action figures based on the Mighty Morphin line was released in early 1996, and were called the “Battle Borgs”. The series included all six Rangers with a new robot style morphing feature.

Battle Borgs Power Rangers

Year Released: 1996

Scarcity Factor: Tough to find on the secondary market.

Notes: The Battle Borg Power Ranger figures were the final series of figures released for the Mighty Morphin Power Rangers line in 1996. This was also the only Mighty Morphin series released this year before transitioning over the the Power Rangers Zeo line. These figures are very difficult to find on the secondary market due to limited production numbers.

Mighty Morphin’ Power Rangers (1993 – 1995): Accessories

Bandai released several role playing accessories for kids to mirror their favorite Ranger characters.

Power Morpher/

Power Gun-Sword

Released 1993

Market Value:

Boxed $175 – $250

Loose $70 – $100

Dragon

Dagger

Released 1994

Market Value:

Boxed $200 – $300

Loose $80 – $120

Power

Cannon

Released 1994

Market Value:

Boxed $85 – $115

Loose $30 – $45

Saba The Tiger Saber

Released 1994

Market Value:

Boxed $150 – $225

Loose $60 – $90

Power Blaster

Released 1995

Market Value:

Boxed $100 – $150

Loose $40 – $60

Power Rangers Accessories

Year Released: 1993, 1994, 1995

Scarcity Factor: Most can still be found, but they are getting tougher to find each year.

Notes: The Mighty Morphin Power Rangers line remains incredibly popular to this day, but most of its accessories can still be found at somewhat reasonable prices. The Dragon Dagger and Saba Tiger Saber are among the more difficult to find items, while the Power Cannon is among the easier to find.

Mighty Morphin’ Power Rangers (1994): Playsets

Bandai only released one actual playset for their Mighty Morphin action figures, and that was the Power Dome Playset in 1994. This was the Rangers headquarters and included the only release of the Rangers mentor, Zordon.

Power Dome Morphin’ Playset

Market Value:

Boxed $150 – $225

Loose $40 – $60

Power Dome Morphin Playset

Year Released: 1994

Accessories: Alpha 5 Figure, Zordon Voice Morpher, Transport Tube, Secret Door, Cycle Launcher, Viewing Globe, Console

Scarcity Factor: Can be a bit challenging to find, especially in good packaging.

Notes: The Mighty Morphin Power Rangers Power Dome Playset was at the top of just about every kid’s Wishlist back in the day. It was the only place that you could find Zordon and an Alpha 5 figure, making this a pretty big deal. Not to mention that it was the only playset released for the Mighty Morphin line, this set remains very popular and can be a bit challenging to find one complete in a good package.

Mighty Morphin’ Power Rangers (1993 – 1995): Vehicles

Three different lines of Ranger vehicles were released during the Mighty Morphin line. This included the Battle Bikes, Thunder Bikes, and the Shark Cycles.

Battle Bikes

Released in 1993

Mammoth Battle Bike

Market Value:

Boxed $40 – $60

Loose $10 – $18

Triceratops Battle Bike

Market Value:

Boxed $40 – $60

Loose $10 – $18

Tyrannosaurus Battle Bike

Market Value:

Boxed $40 – $60

Loose $10 – $18

Thunder Bikes

Released in 1995 (Spring)

Shark Cycles

Released in 1995 (Fall)

Power Rangers Vehicles

Year Released: 1993, 1994, 1995

Scarcity Factor: Most vehicles can still be found, but they are getting tougher to find each year.

Notes: The Mighty Morphin Power Rangers line remains incredibly popular to this day, but most of its vehicles can still be found at somewhat reasonable prices. The Battle Bikes and Thunder Bikes are definitely easier to locate on the secondary market than the Shark Cycles, which were a later release.

Mighty Morphin’ Power Rangers (1993 – 1995): Vehicles – Zords

Zords are vehicles, which are controlled by each Ranger. These Zords are used to battle enemies when they grow to larger sizes. They can also combine into a larger Megazord when needed. There were several Zords released during the Mighty Morphin Power Rangers run between 1993 and 1995, and they typically bring high prices on today’s secondary market.

1993

Scarcity Factor: The initial 1993 Zords are difficult to find on the secondary market.

Notes: The Mighty Morphin Power Rangers line were incredibly popular when released, and that continues to this day. This is especially true with the Zord released in 1993. They are definitely on the expensive side, and can be tough to find, especially in good and complete packaged condition.

1994

Scarcity Factor: The Zord releases from 1994 can be challenging to find on the secondary market.

Notes: The Mighty Morphin Power Ranger Zords released in 1994 were just as popular as previously released in 1993. The Deluxe Thunder Megazord and Special Sized Thunder Megazord are among the harder to find from this group.

Deluxe

Thunder Megazord

Market Value:

Boxed $250 – $350

Loose $90 – $130

Red Dragon

Thunderzord

Market Value:

Boxed $100 – $140

Loose $35 – $55

Thunderzord

Assault Team

Market Value:

Boxed $150 – $200

Loose $50 – $75

Thunder Megazord

(Special Sized)

Market Value:

Boxed $350 – $450

Loose $90 – $140

Tor the Shuttlezord

Market Value:

Boxed $160 – $210

Loose $65 – $90

White Tigerzord with

White Ranger

Market Value:

Boxed $175 – $250

Loose $80 – $120

1995

Scarcity Factor: Most of the Zord releases from 1995 are easier to locate on the secondary market, with some exceptions.

Notes: The Mighty Morphin Power Ranger Zords released in 1995 were still very popular, but more were produced so they were a bit easier to find. The Deluxe Movie Ninja Megazord, White Ranger’s Movie Deluxe Falconzord and Lord Zedd’s Serpentera are among the harder to locate Zords from this group.

Deluxe Auto-Morphin

Ninjor

Market Value:

Boxed $85 – $115

Loose $35 – $55

Ninja

Megafalconzord

Market Value:

Boxed $100 – $140

Loose $40 – $60

Ninja

Megafalconzord (Movie)

Market Value:

Boxed $90 – $120

Loose $35 – $55

The Return

Of Titanus

Market Value:

Boxed $100 – $150

Loose $40 – $60

White Ranger’s

Deluxe Falconzord

Market Value:

Boxed $90 – $140

Loose $35 – $55

White Ranger’s Deluxe

Falconzord (Movie)

Market Value:

Boxed $200 – $275

Loose $40 – $60

The Power Rangers are one of the most iconic franchises in today’s toy world, and have been a staple on the small screen and toy aisles since 1993, but their journey to getting to that point was a long and sometimes complicated one, to say the least. In 1992, Saban Entertainment purchased the U.S distribution rights to the popular Japanese television show, Super Sentai. The show, about a group of super hero teens, was adopted into an English speaking format called the “Mighty Morphin Power Rangers”, which debuted in August of 1993, and the rest, as they say, is history.

The television series initially consisted of five Power Ranger characters, Red Ranger, Blue Ranger, Black Ranger, Yellow Ranger and the Pink Ranger. These Rangers would go on to battle a small army of different and very……….unique villains called “Evil Space Aliens”. A sixth Ranger, Tommy, would later be added. He would known as the Green Ranger, and later on, the White Ranger. Multiple waves of action figures would fill the toy aisles of retail stores during this time, featuring various iterations of the Rangers characters, along with the evil aliens. The Mighty Morphin Power Rangers Movie was released in 1995, which spawned new lines of figures based on the movie characters. Several Zords and Vehicles would also be released during this Mighty Morphin line from 1993 to 1995.

The figures and accessories from this initial line of Power Rangers from 1993 to 1995 are generally considered to be modern day classics, and built the foundation of the Power Rangers franchise as we know them today. This particular line remains the largest one from the Power Rangers franchise, with the most released products of any other Rangers iteration. This toy line is fondly remembered by the kids of this generation and remain highly sought after in today’s secondary market.
